df-lno
blocks.content: Define the class of linear operators between two normed complex vector spaces. In the literature, an operator may be a partial function, i.e. the domain of an operator is not necessarily the entire vector space. However, since the domain of a linear operator is a vector subspace, we define it with a complete function for convenience and will use subset relations to specify the partial function case. (Contributed by NM, 6-Nov-2007.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-lno(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5) {
  |- wceq(clno, cmpo(s0, s1, cnv, cnv, crab(s2, co(cfv(cba, cv(s1)), cmap, cfv(cba, cv(s0))), wral(s3, cc, wral(s4, cfv(cba, cv(s0)), wral(s5, cfv(cba, cv(s0)), wceq(cfv(cv(s2), co(co(cv(s3), cfv(cns, cv(s0)), cv(s4)), cfv(cpv, cv(s0)), cv(s5))), co(co(cv(s3), cfv(cns, cv(s1)), cfv(cv(s2), cv(s4))), cfv(cpv, cv(s1)), cfv(cv(s2), cv(s5))))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s5)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s5)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s5)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s5)
  -| diffss(s4, s5)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-lno(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5) {
  ⊢ LnOp =(s0 ∈ NrmCVec, s1 ∈ NrmCVec ↦ { s2 ∈((BaseSet ` s1)[↦](BaseSet ` s0))| ∀(s3 ∈ ℂ, ∀(s4 ∈(BaseSet ` s0), ∀(s5 ∈(BaseSet ` s0),(s2 `((s3[(.sOLD ` s0)]s4)[(+v ` s0)]s5))=((s3[(.sOLD ` s1)](s2 ` s4))[(+v ` s1)](s2 ` s5)))))})
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
  ⊣ d(s2, s4)
  ⊣ d(s2, s5)
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s0, s4)
  ⊣ d(s0, s5)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s4)
  ⊣ d(s1, s5)
  ⊣ d(s3, s4)
  ⊣ d(s3, s5)
  ⊣ d(s4, s5)
}

blocks.name: df-nmoo
blocks.content: Define the norm of an operator between two normed complex vector spaces. This definition produces an operator norm function for each pair of vector spaces ` <. u , w >. ` . Based on definition of linear operator norm in [AkhiezerGlazman] p. 39, although we define it for all operators for convenience. It isn't necessarily meaningful for nonlinear operators, since it doesn't take into account operator values at vectors with norm greater than 1. See Equation 2 of [Kreyszig] p. 92 for a definition that does (although it ignores the value at the zero vector). However, operator norms are rarely if ever used for nonlinear operators. (Contributed by NM, 6-Nov-2007.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-nmoo(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(cnmoo, cmpo(s0, s1, cnv, cnv, cmpt(s2, co(cfv(cba, cv(s1)), cmap, cfv(cba, cv(s0))), csup(cab(s3, wrex(s4, cfv(cba, cv(s0)), wa(wbr(cfv(cfv(cnmcv, cv(s0)), cv(s4)), cle, nat1), wceq(cv(s3), cfv(cfv(cnmcv, cv(s1)), cfv(cv(s2), cv(s4))))))), cxr, clt))))
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-nmoo(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ⊢ normOpOLD =(s0 ∈ NrmCVec, s1 ∈ NrmCVec ↦(s2 ∈((BaseSet ` s1)[↦](BaseSet ` s0))↦ sup({ s3 | ∃(s4 ∈(BaseSet ` s0),(((normCV ` s0)` s4)[≤]1 ∧ s3 =((normCV ` s1)`(s2 ` s4))))}, ℝ*, <)))
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
  ⊣ d(s2, s4)
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s0, s4)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s4)
  ⊣ d(s3, s4)
}

df-aj
blocks.content: Define the adjoint of an operator (if it exists). The domain of ` U adj W ` is the set of all operators from ` U ` to ` W ` that have an adjoint. Definition 3.9-1 of [Kreyszig] p. 196, although we don't require that ` U ` and ` W ` be Hilbert spaces nor that the operators be linear. Although we define it for any normed vector space for convenience, the definition is meaningful only for inner product spaces. (Contributed by NM, 25-Jan-2008.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-aj(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5) {
  |- wceq(caj, cmpo(s0, s1, cnv, cnv, copab(s2, s3, w3a(wf(cv(s2), cfv(cba, cv(s0)), cfv(cba, cv(s1))), wf(cv(s3), cfv(cba, cv(s1)), cfv(cba, cv(s0))), wral(s4, cfv(cba, cv(s0)), wral(s5, cfv(cba, cv(s1)), wceq(co(cfv(cv(s2), cv(s4)), cfv(cdip, cv(s1)), cv(s5)), co(cv(s4), cfv(cdip, cv(s0)), cfv(cv(s3), cv(s5))))))))))
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s3, s5)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s5)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s5)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s1, s5)
  -| diffss(s4, s5)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-aj(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4, setvar s5) {
  ⊢ adj =(s0 ∈ NrmCVec, s1 ∈ NrmCVec ↦ { < s2, s3 > |((s2 :(BaseSet ` s0)→(BaseSet ` s1))∧(s3 :(BaseSet ` s1)→(BaseSet ` s0))∧ ∀(s4 ∈(BaseSet ` s0), ∀(s5 ∈(BaseSet ` s1),((s2 ` s4)[(.iOLD ` s1)]s5)=(s4[(.iOLD ` s0)](s3 ` s5)))))})
  ⊣ d(s2, s3)
  ⊣ d(s0, s3)
  ⊣ d(s1, s3)
  ⊣ d(s3, s4)
  ⊣ d(s3, s5)
  ⊣ d(s0, s2)
  ⊣ d(s1, s2)
  ⊣ d(s2, s4)
  ⊣ d(s2, s5)
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
  ⊣ d(s0, s4)
  ⊣ d(s0, s5)
  ⊣ d(s1, s4)
  ⊣ d(s1, s5)
  ⊣ d(s4, s5)
}

blocks.name: df-hmo
blocks.content: Define the set of Hermitian (self-adjoint) operators on a normed complex vector space (normally a Hilbert space). Although we define it for any normed vector space for convenience, the definition is meaningful only for inner product spaces. (Contributed by NM, 26-Jan-2008.) (New usage is discouraged.)

thm islno(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, class c8, class c9) {

  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cba, c0))
  -| wceq(c5, cfv(cba, c1))
  -| wceq(c7, cfv(cpv, c0))
  -| wceq(c9, cfv(cpv, c1))
  -| wceq(c6, cfv(cns, c0))
  -| wceq(c8, cfv(cns, c1))
  -| wceq(c3, co(c0, clno, c1))

  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)

  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c4)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c1)
  -| diffsc(s2, c2)
  -| diffsc(s2, c4)
} = {
  syl6bb(wa(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, cnv)), wcel(c2, c3), wa(wf(c2, c4, c5), wral(s0, cc, wral(s1, c4, wral(s2, c4, wceq(cfv(c2, co(co(cv(s0), c6, cv(s1)), c7, cv(s2))), co(co(cv(s0), c8, cfv(c2, cv(s1))), c9, cfv(c2, cv(s2)))))))), wcel(c2, crab(hs0, co(c5, cmap, c4), wral(s0, cc, wral(s1, c4, wral(s2, c4, wceq(cfv(cv(hs0), co(co(cv(s0), c6, cv(s1)), c7, cv(s2))), co(co(cv(s0), c8, cfv(cv(hs0), cv(s1))), c9, cfv(cv(hs0), cv(s2))))))))))

  syl5eq(c2, crab(s0, c3, wbr(cfv(c4, cv(s0)), clt, cpnf)), co(c0, cblo, c1), wa(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, cnv)))

  rabeqbidv(s0, co(cv(hs0), clno, cv(hs1)), co(c0, clno, cv(hs1)), wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wbr(cfv(co(cv(hs0), cnmoo, cv(hs1)), cv(s0)), clt, cpnf), wbr(cfv(co(c0, cnmoo, cv(hs1)), cv(s0)), clt, cpnf))

  fveq1d(co(c0, cnmoo, cv(hs1)), cv(s0), c4, wceq(cv(hs1), c1))

  rabeqbidv(s0, (hs0[LnOp]hs1), (c0[LnOp]hs1), hs0 = c0, ((hs0[normOpOLD]hs1)` s0)[<]+∞, ((c0[normOpOLD]hs1)` s0)[<]+∞)
  oveq1(hs0, c0, clno, hs1)
  breq1d(((hs0[normOpOLD]hs1)` s0), clt, cpnf, ((c0[normOpOLD]hs1)` s0), hs0 = c0)
  fveq1d((hs0[normOpOLD]hs1), s0, (c0[normOpOLD]hs1), hs0 = c0)
  oveq1(hs0, c0, cnmoo, hs1)
  rabeqbidv(s0, (c0[LnOp]hs1), c3, hs1 = c1, ((c0[normOpOLD]hs1)` s0)[<]+∞, (c4 ` s0)[<]+∞)

  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(cnv)

  diff.hs1.c(c1)
  diff.hs1.c({ s0 ∈ c3 |(c4 ` s0)[<]+∞ })

  diff.co.s(s0, c0, clno, hs1)

blocks.content: An upper bound for the operator norm of a linear operator, using only the properties of nonzero arguments. (Contributed by NM, 1-Jan-2008.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: blocnilem
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ blocni and ~ lnocni . If a linear operator is continuous at any point, it is bounded. (Contributed by NM, 17-Dec-2007.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 10-Jan-2014.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: blocni
blocks.content: A linear operator is continuous iff it is bounded. Theorem 2.7-9(a) of [Kreyszig] p. 97. (Contributed by NM, 18-Dec-2007.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 10-Jan-2014.) (New usage is discouraged.)

blocks.name: lnocni
blocks.content: If a linear operator is continuous at any point, it is continuous everywhere. Theorem 2.7-9(b) of [Kreyszig] p. 97. (Contributed by NM, 18-Dec-2007.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm lnocni(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, class c7, class c8, class c9, class c10) {
  |- wi(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cfv(co(c3, ccnp, c4), c0))), wcel(c2, co(c3, ccn, c4)))
  -| wceq(c5, cfv(cims, c6))
  -| wceq(c7, cfv(cims, c8))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(cmopn, c5))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cmopn, c7))
  -| wceq(c9, co(c6, clno, c8))
  -| wceq(c10, co(c6, cblo, c8))
  -| wcel(c6, cnv)
  -| wcel(c8, cnv)
  -| wcel(c2, c9)
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cba, c6))
} = {
  sylibr(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c2, cfv(co(c3, ccnp, c4), c0))), wcel(c2, co(c3, ccn, c4)), wcel(c2, c10))
  blocnilem(c0, c1, c2, c3, c4, c10, c5, c6, c7, c8, c9)
  blocni(c2, c3, c4, c10, c5, c6, c7, c8, c9)
}

blocks.name: hmoval
blocks.content: The set of Hermitian (self-adjoint) operators on a normed complex vector space. (Contributed by NM, 26-Jan-2008.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 16-Nov-2013.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm hmoval(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cnv), wceq(c1, crab(s0, cdm(c2), wceq(cfv(c2, cv(s0)), cv(s0)))))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(chmo, c0))
  -| wceq(c2, co(c0, caj, c0))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
} = {
  syl5eq(c1, crab(s0, cdm(c2), wceq(cfv(c2, cv(s0)), cv(s0))), cfv(chmo, c0), wcel(c0, cnv))
  fvmpt(hs0, c0, cnv, chmo, crab(s0, cdm(c2), wceq(cfv(c2, cv(s0)), cv(s0))), crab(s0, cdm(co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0))), wceq(cfv(co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0)), cv(s0)), cv(s0))))
  rabeqbidv(s0, cdm(co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0))), cdm(c2), wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wceq(cfv(co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0)), cv(s0)), cv(s0)), wceq(cfv(c2, cv(s0)), cv(s0)))
  dmeqd(co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0)), c2, wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  eqeq1d(cfv(co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0)), cv(s0)), cv(s0), cfv(c2, cv(s0)), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  fveq1d(co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0)), cv(s0), c2, wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  syl6eqr(co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0)), c2, co(c0, caj, c0), wceq(cv(hs0), c0))
  anidms(wceq(cv(hs0), c0), wceq(co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0)), co(c0, caj, c0)))
  oveq12(cv(hs0), c0, cv(hs0), c0, caj)
  df-hmo(hs0, s0)
  rabex(s0, cdm(c2), wceq(cfv(c2, cv(s0)), cv(s0)))
  dmex(c2)
  eqeltri(c2, universe, co(c0, caj, c0))
  ovex(c0, caj, c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(cnv)
  diff.hs0.c(crab(s0, cdm(c2), wceq(cfv(c2, cv(s0)), cv(s0))))
  diff.cdm.s(s0, co(cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0)))
  diff.co.s(s0, cv(hs0), caj, cv(hs0))
  diff.caj.s(s0)
  diff.cdm.s(s0, c2)
  diff.wceq.s(s0, cv(hs0), c0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
}

thm hmoval(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ NrmCVec → c1 = { s0 ∈ dom(c2)|(c2 ` s0)= s0 })
  ⊣ c1 =(HmOp ` c0)
  ⊣ c2 =(c0[adj]c0)
  ⊣ d(s0, c0)
  ⊣ d(s0, c2)
} = {
  syl5eq(c1, { s0 ∈ dom(c2)|(c2 ` s0)= s0 }, (HmOp ` c0), c0 ∈ NrmCVec)
  fvmpt(hs0, c0, cnv, chmo, { s0 ∈ dom(c2)|(c2 ` s0)= s0 }, { s0 ∈ dom((hs0[adj]hs0))|((hs0[adj]hs0)` s0)= s0 })
  rabeqbidv(s0, dom((hs0[adj]hs0)), dom(c2), hs0 = c0, ((hs0[adj]hs0)` s0)= s0, (c2 ` s0)= s0)
  dmeqd((hs0[adj]hs0), c2, hs0 = c0)
  eqeq1d(((hs0[adj]hs0)` s0), s0, (c2 ` s0), hs0 = c0)
  fveq1d((hs0[adj]hs0), s0, c2, hs0 = c0)
  syl6eqr((hs0[adj]hs0), c2, (c0[adj]c0), hs0 = c0)
  anidms(hs0 = c0, (hs0[adj]hs0)=(c0[adj]c0))
  oveq12(hs0, c0, hs0, c0, caj)
  df-hmo(hs0, s0)
  rabex(s0, dom(c2), (c2 ` s0)= s0)
  dmex(c2)
  eqeltri(c2, universe, (c0[adj]c0))
  ovex(c0, caj, c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(cnv)
  diff.hs0.c({ s0 ∈ dom(c2)|(c2 ` s0)= s0 })
  diff.cdm.s(s0, (hs0[adj]hs0))
  diff.co.s(s0, hs0, caj, hs0)
  diff.caj.s(s0)
  diff.cdm.s(s0, c2)
  diff.wceq.s(s0, hs0, c0)
  diff.cv.s(s0, hs0)
  diffss.ex(s0, hs0)
  diff.hs0.s(s0)
}

blocks.name: ishmo
blocks.content: The predicate "is a hermitian operator." (Contributed by NM, 26-Jan-2008.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm ishmo(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  |- wi(wcel(c0, cnv), wb(wcel(c1, c2), wa(wcel(c1, cdm(c3)), wceq(cfv(c3, c1), c1))))
  -| wceq(c2, cfv(chmo, c0))
  -| wceq(c3, co(c0, caj, c0))
} = {
  syl6bb(wcel(c0, cnv), wcel(c1, c2), wa(wcel(c1, cdm(c3)), wceq(cfv(c3, c1), c1)), wcel(c1, crab(hs0, cdm(c3), wceq(cfv(c3, cv(hs0)), cv(hs0)))))
  eleq2d(c1, c2, crab(hs0, cdm(c3), wceq(cfv(c3, cv(hs0)), cv(hs0))), wcel(c0, cnv))
  hmoval(hs0, c0, c2, c3)
  elrab(hs0, c1, cdm(c3), wceq(cfv(c3, cv(hs0)), cv(hs0)), wceq(cfv(c3, c1), c1))
  eqeq12d(cfv(c3, cv(hs0)), cv(hs0), cfv(c3, c1), c1, wceq(cv(hs0), c1))
  fveq2(cv(hs0), c1, c3)
  id(wceq(cv(hs0), c1))
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c3)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(cdm(c3))
  diff.hs0.w(wceq(cfv(c3, c1), c1))
}
blocks.pretty:
thm ishmo(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈ NrmCVec →(c1 ∈ c2 ↔(c1 ∈ dom(c3)∧(c3 ` c1)= c1)))
  ⊣ c2 =(HmOp ` c0)
  ⊣ c3 =(c0[adj]c0)
} = {
  syl6bb(c0 ∈ NrmCVec, c1 ∈ c2, (c1 ∈ dom(c3)∧(c3 ` c1)= c1), c1 ∈ { hs0 ∈ dom(c3)|(c3 ` hs0)= hs0 })
  eleq2d(c1, c2, { hs0 ∈ dom(c3)|(c3 ` hs0)= hs0 }, c0 ∈ NrmCVec)
  hmoval(hs0, c0, c2, c3)
  elrab(hs0, c1, dom(c3), (c3 ` hs0)= hs0, (c3 ` c1)= c1)
  eqeq12d((c3 ` hs0), hs0, (c3 ` c1), c1, hs0 = c1)
  fveq2(hs0, c1, c3)
  id(hs0 = c1)
  diff.hs0.c(c0)
  diff.hs0.c(c3)
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(dom(c3))
  diff.hs0.w((c3 ` c1)= c1)
}
